payload.name: non-monotonic
payload.core: Adding information can retract previous conclusions. Unlike classical logic where more premises yield more conclusions, new facts may invalidate earlier defaults ('birds fly' until 'penguin').

out.d: new facts that retract previous conclusions
specificity or preference among conflicting defaults

proc: identify default rules: 'normally X implies Y'
apply defaults in absence of contradicting information
check for exceptions: does new info defeat any active default
resolve conflicts via priority or specificity
check: conclusions marked as tentative vs certain

diff.deductive: deduction is monotonic; non-monotonic allows retraction
diff.belief-revision: revision updates belief sets; non-monotonic handles defaults at inference time
diff.defeasible: defeasible tracks defeat relations; non-monotonic focuses on exception patterns
diff.default-typicality: typicality is specific mechanism; non-monotonic is broader framework

signals: conflicting defaults with no resolution rule
mitigations: explicit priority ordering for all default pairs
specificity principle: more specific defeats general

ex.sit: Policy: employees get standard leave. Exception: contractors get reduced leave. Exception: senior contractors get standard leave.
steps: apply specificity: senior-contractor more specific than contractor
conclude: Bob gets standard leave (not reduced)
if learn Bob is intern: retract, re-evaluate
ex.insight: more specific exception defeats general default; new info can retract
